image.altText: A thumb tapping a Google app on a smartphone

props.synopsis: The government has agreed to proposals that would allow Australians to opt out of targeted advertising, require search engines to "de-index" certain information about them, and draw small businesses into Australia's privacy scheme.

title.children: Opting out of targeted ads, and a 'right to be forgotten': Government agrees to sweeping privacy reforms

image.altText: a composite image of chris fagan on left and kevin walters on right, both look happy

props.synopsis: This weekend is the first time in history Brisbane's AFL and NRL teams have both played in a grand final in the same season. These are the stories of the men who orchestrated the occasion.

title.children: Brisbane's teams have already made history. They could claim glory too — led by coaches with very different backstories

props.synopsis: The separatist government of Nagorno-Karabakh has announced it will dissolve itself and the unrecognised republic will cease to exist by the end of the year as more than half of the ethnic Armenian population has already fled.

title.children: Nagorno-Karabakh's separatist government says it will dissolve as more than half of ethnic Armenians flee

image.altText: Michael Gambon as Dumbeldore in Harry Potter

props.synopsis: Michael Gambon, who played Dumbledore in Harry Potter, has died peacefully in hospital, according to a family statement.

title.children: Harry Potter actor Sir Michael Gambon, dies aged 82

image.altText: Tom Robinson takes a selfie nearthe water

props.synopsis: When Tom Robinson starts rowing from Vanuatu on Friday, there are two things he will be looking forward to when he arrives back in Australia.

title.children: Brisbane man begins ‘make-or-break’ leg in record-breaking row boat journey

image.altText: An Australian MP stands at a lecturn with three people, including Taiwan's President on stage behind him.

props.synopsis: China's ambassador lashes out at Australian politicians who have recently visited Taiwan, saying the MPs are being manipulated by separatist forces inside the self-governed territory.

title.children: China warns Australia to think twice before sending MPs to Taiwan

image.altText: A drone shot of people on an island

props.synopsis: The island of Aorigi is a remote dot on the map south-east of the Solomon Islands' capital. And here on this day of celebration, spears fly.

title.children: On a remote beach in Solomon Islands, family members sort out differences with spears. Another threat is proving more dangerous

image.altText: Justice Dixon wears a dark suit jacket, white shirt and orange and blue tie and smiles closed mouthed outside the Supreme Court

props.synopsis: In the final moments of his 40-year legal career, outgoing Supreme Court judge John Dixon called for constitutional recognition of Indigenous Australians and made a thinly veiled swipe at some of those opposing it.

title.children: Retiring Supreme Court judge takes aim at 'shameful' conflict over Voice referendum

image.altText: A composite image of three men smiling

props.synopsis: Police are working to determine the cause of a head-on collision in Baldivis in Perth's southern suburbs that has left three men dead and two other people in hospital.

title.children: Tributes pour in after three young men killed in head-on crash

image.altText: A helicopter dropping water onto a bushfire.

props.synopsis: Under the new system, parts of Australia have already faced catastrophic warnings this fire season. But some of those alerts were wrong.

title.children: Australia's new $11m fire warning system is exaggerating the risks, ABC investigation reveals

image.altText: A close up of a woman in a denim jacket smiling, next to a photo of a man in a t-shirt smiling and holding a mobile phone.

props.synopsis: Meta — the parent company of Facebook, Instagram and WhatsApp — unveils new celebrity AI chatbots, smart glasses and a refreshed mixed reality headset.

title.children: The Matildas' Sam Kerr has been turned into an AI chatbot, and Mark Zuckerberg says there are 'a lot more coming'

image.altText: A little girl sits in a sandpit, surrounded by yellow toy dump trucks.

props.synopsis: A new kind of pay negotiation is underway between childcare workers and their employers, as unions seek 25 per cent pay bump.

title.children: Childcare workers could be set for a substantial pay rise as multi-employer bargaining begins

image.altText: Department of Transport officials sitting in the airline inquiry.

props.synopsis: A parliamentary committee investigating the government's rejection of extra Qatar Airways flights is increasing its rhetoric in a bid to land high-profile witnesses.

title.children: Former Qantas boss Alan Joyce faces jail threat over Senate airline inquiry

image.altText: A woman wearing glasses sits in a chair listening to a man ask her questions

props.synopsis: The ex-Lateline host gave evidence about her interview with former detective Pamela Young in 2015, regarding the death of American Scott Johnson.

title.children: 'Outrageous': Emma Alberici fronts gay hate crimes inquiry over ABC detective interview

image.altText: Sun setting through a line of transmission towers

props.synopsis: The NSW government is currently in talks with Origin about using taxpayer subsidies to extend the life of the plant in the state's Hunter region. It follows a review that found the state should discuss delaying the plant's closure to help prevent blackouts due to the slow building of renewables.

title.children: '$1.7b in damages a year': The estimated cost of keeping Australia's largest coal-fired power plant running

image.altText: Geoffrey Blainey makes a hand gesture while delivering a speech

props.synopsis: In an opinion piece published in The Australian, historian Geoffrey Blainey said Indigenous people were counted in every federal census since 1901. Is that correct? RMIT ABC Fact Check investigates.

title.children: We fact checked Geoffrey Blainey on counting Indigenous people in the census. Here's what we found

image.altText: Tiwi Bombers footy players line up with linked arms

props.synopsis: Multiple suicides have left communities mourning in the Top End of the Northern Territory, as new data shows an alarming increase in the jurisdiction's suicide rate.

title.children: Prominent Tiwi footballer among series of suicides in remote NT, as data shows territory rate climbing

image.altText: A man sits at a table covered in drinks as he waves a cigarette in his hand.

props.synopsis: A powerful village chief invited dozens of police officers to his house for a wild party. But when one of them wound up dead, it kicked off a huge scandal that threatens the unchecked power of Thailand’s authorities.

title.children: A Thai village chief invited dozens of cops for dinner. Then he allegedly told his henchman to kill one

image.altText: A sky light pops through the grass.

props.synopsis: Designers of "earth-sheltered" homes say interest in living underground is rising as the risk of bushfires increases and more days of extreme heat are forecast.

title.children: Why more of us are opting to live underground to escape bushfires and extreme heat

image.altText: Mr Vo wears a black leather jacket and carries a green shopping bag while his wife holds his arm and covers her face.

props.synopsis: The court has heard Vo Ngoc Thanh appeared to be practising driving when he hit two boys playing in a laneway at Braybrook, in Melbourne's west.

title.children: Unlicensed driver who pinned boy between vehicles allegedly mistook 'accelator for the brake'

image.altText: Padlocked school

props.synopsis: A new bushfire risk register is being used to decide which schools close and which stay open during dangerous conditions. This is how it works.

title.children: NSW schools may close in hot weather this term — but some parents say it's not sustainable

image.altText: A for sale sign outside a suburban home

props.synopsis: A "slight uptick" in inflation is unlikely to see the Reserve Bank lift rates at its October meeting, but households facing a fixed-rate mortgage cliff are warned to brace for higher repayments.

title.children: Half a million households brace for higher interest rates by the end of the year as the mortgage cliff looms

image.altText: A steam-engine train travels along, puffing steam.

props.synopsis: Police say the miniature steam-engine train derailed about 10am today, injuring several people.

title.children: Four hospitalised after miniature steam train derails at Canberra's Cockington Green Gardens

props.synopsis: Townsville is emerging as Australia's new Army capital with hundreds of soldiers to be relocated over coming years, while Adelaide becomes the home of advanced land-based, long-range strike technology.

title.children: Townsville emerges as new 'capital' of Army in Defence Force shake up

image.altText: A woman gives a heavy metal hand gesture

props.synopsis: Women who came up against barriers when breaking into the heavy metal music scene celebrate their resilience as they continue their push for change.

title.children: Women breaking glass ceilings in the world of heavy metal

image.altText: Danushka Gunathilaka talks to the media outside court

props.synopsis: The 32-year-old was arrested in November while in Australia for the T-20 World Cup, after he went for drinks with the woman near the Sydney Opera House before going back to her eastern suburbs home.

title.children: Cricketer Danushka Gunathilaka found not guilty of sexually assaulting Sydney woman

image.altText: A middle-aged woman with short hair and glasses looking pensively by some bushes

props.synopsis: Some of the disability royal commission's most compelling evidence has come from mothers who lost their children. On the eve of the final report, two mums share their stories and hopes for the future.

title.children: Nella's daughter died in disability care. She wants to make sure no-one else goes through the same pain

image.altText: A large light grey dugong and small fish move through clear blue waters eating seagrass off sandy ocean floor.

props.synopsis: James Cook University research reveals a long-term decline in the vulnerable species on a large stretch of the Queensland coast.

title.children: Dugong population decline on Great Barrier Reef sparks call for urgent action
